Question:
Downturn in the growth of the world’s leading economies
In February 2016 there were dramatic changes in both financial and commodity markets across the world. Central bank interest rates in some countries were at their lowest recorded level, prices of banking shares fell heavily and oil prices in New York fell to US$26.34 a barrel, the lowest in 13 years.
Economists warned that the falls in share prices could indicate a downturn for economies with a possible collapse of banks, as happened in the financial crash of 2008. A healthy banking system is needed to promote economic growth. Very low interest rates undermine the profitability of commercial banks.
Overproduction of oil by Saudi Arabia, the leader of the oil cartel OPEC, created price falls and deficits in the budgets of its OPEC partners that resulted in contractions in the economies of oilexporting countries. On the other hand, oil importing countries benefited from lower production costs although their governments claimed that revenues from sales taxes on oil products fell.
Also in 2016, China’s demand for oil fell because of a downturn in its economy. In 2010 China’s economy grew by 10%. By 2015 the rate had fallen to 6.9%. Some critics said that China’s high economic growth was enabled by the excessive borrowing of the central government to build massive infrastructure projects – such as roads, offices and factories. This meant that the government owed huge amounts to banks driving them towards bankruptcy. These debts were linked to excess capacity in the construction and manufacturing industries.
The Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) expressed concern at the state of the global economy in 2016. It criticised the over-reliance by some of the world’s major economies on monetary policies based on low interest rates and quantitative easing. It argued that monetary policy cannot work alone to boost an economy and that fiscal expansion was needed to increase aggregate demand and aggregate supply. By 2016, many economies had reduced government spending and aimed at cutting budget deficits. As a result the OECD reduced its GDP growth forecasts in 2016. Question:
The effects of European Union (EU) labour migration
In 2016 in the EU labour market there was free movement of people seeking work among the EU's 28 member countries. One country reported that an extra 252000 workers from other EU countries came to work there during 2014–2015. This meant that the total number of EU workers was 2.1 million, or 6.8% of the country's workforce. The eight Eastern European countries that joined the EU in 2004 supplied 987000 of those workers by 2015.
A critic of this free movement of labour stated that "It is the workers on low pay in the receiving country – and those out of work – who feel the consequences of uncontrolled migration. They are forced to compete for jobs with thousands of people from abroad, and they suffer downward pressures on their wages."
In contrast, other studies have shown that migration of workers has been good for both economic growth and public finances. These studies reported "There is no correlation between high migration and unemployment. Unemployment fell significantly as total migration rose to a record level of 392000 in May 2014. Migration is acknowledged to be positive for public finances. In the EU, migrants contributed US$25 billion more in taxes in the decade to 2011 than they used in welfare and public services. Wages may have been affected for low-skilled workers but only marginally downward."
Other economists have argued that, in theory, "the impacts of immigration on wages and employment critically depends on whether migrants' skills are complements to, or substitutes for, the skills of existing workers. These impacts vary between the short run and long run. In the short run if the skills of migrants and existing workers are substitutes, immigration can be expected to increase competition in the labour market and drive down wages. If, on the other hand, the skills of migrants are complementary to those of existing workers, all workers experience increased productivity which can be expected to lead to a rise in wages of existing workers. In the long run the economy can adjust to the increase in labour supply."
Some governments have introduced a minimum wage to help those workers on low pay. The wage is set to increase to match any increase in inflation.

Question:
Increasing public sector debt is a good policy
Politicians do not usually think it a success to borrow a large amount of money but, in June 2020, when the economy was approaching a recession, the United Kingdom (UK) borrowed five times as much as it did in June 2019. This made the government debt only just a little less than the total size of the economy. The ratio of public sector debt to gross domestic product (GDP) was 99.6%. It was the highest figure for 60 years. Public sector net borrowing is shown in Fig. 1.

Borrowing is what the government ought to be doing in a recession in order to finance the spending used to boost aggregate demand. The question in 2020 was how long could the borrowing of such large amounts continue? There can be problems with a large public sector debt. An expansion of government borrowing might increase interest rates if investors require more compensation because they think the risk of holding government bonds has increased. This interest rate rise would affect the rest of the economy.
There is also a theoretical objection that government borrowing could 'crowd out' the private sector, especially when the economy is close to its productive capacity and unemployment of resources is low. This would not happen when there are unemployed resources in a recession. 
The UK Finance Minister suggested that a high ratio of public sector debt to GDP was justified; it is the stability of the ratio that is important. This reasoning can be justified. Reducing government spending in order to reduce borrowing would risk stopping any recovery and make the situation worse. Economic recovery is necessary to restore economic activity, which in turn will restore the government's finances.
However, economists cannot know with any precision what the limits of public sector borrowing should be. For many years, Japan has maintained a ratio of public sector debt to GDP of over 200% with no difficulty. But what is suitable for Japan may not be suitable in a different type of economy.
Source: The Times, 24 July 2020

Extract 2: Winners and losers in the US–China trade war
The US government imposed a first round of tariffs on Chinese goods on 6 July 2018, by introducing 25% taxes on US$34 billion of Chinese imports. These were a response to China’s“unfair trade policies” – the US claimed China was selling Chinese products in the US below their normal price, called ‘dumping’, as well as subsidising the production of goods exported to the US. It was then announced that tariffs on a further US$50 billion worth of imports from China would come into effect. The US threats have risen since, with the president saying he is ready to impose tariffs on all US$500 billion of Chinese imports.
China has retaliated, saying it will levy new tariffs on more than 5200 US products, if the US government proceeds with its latest tariff threat. The duties would range from 5% to 25% on US$60 billion worth of US products imported into China, including further agricultural products such as soya beans.

Both countries will lose in a major trade war, but the losses will differ in kind and amount. It could cut China’s exports to the US by about a third, some US$200 billion annually. Eventually, Chinese firms will find new markets and create new products to compensate. For a period of two or three years, however, the disruption to workers and firms will be enormous. As many as 4 million Chinese workers could become unemployed, and many Chinese firms will go out of business. 
If US exports to China are cut by a third in a major trade war, the US will lose about US$50 billion of exports annually. About 250000 US workers will lose their jobs. If US firms can see no end to the trade war, they will reorganise and locate production in lower-cost countries like Vietnam and Peru. Worldwide production of palm oil has been increasing for many years. Between 1995 and 2015, annual production quadrupled. The amount of land taken to produce palm oil is vast. It accounts for 10% of all global cropland.

The worldwide demand has raised incomes, especially in the rural areas of Malaysia and Indonesia that produce 85% of the output of palm oil. After the global economic crisis of 1998, the region had been suffering from a significant decline in the exports of manufactured goods. This had a detrimental effect on the balance of payments and resulted in external debt. 
Nations producing palm oil view it as a means of reducing poverty, while international finance organisations regard it as an engine of growth for developing economies. Palm oil's versatility is not limited to food. It is used in 70% of personal care products (toiletries) such as soap, shampoo and make-up. It is also increasingly used as biodiesel fuel.

Question: Discuss, using indifference curve analysis, how the impact of an increase in indirect taxation on the quantity demanded of a good depends on whether it is a normal or inferior good. [13]
Mark Scheme:
b
Indirect tax increases the relative price of a good and there will be both income and substitution effects. These must be shown using indifference curves. Discussion of relative size of income and substitution effects for normal and inferior goods. L4 (9–13 marks) For a thorough explanation of the impact of the indirect tax on both types of good together with relevant diagrams. A discussion on the substitution and income effects of the tax increase. Maximum 11 if no conclusion. L3 (7–8 marks) For a competent explanation which does not fully analyse both types of goods. Full analysis of one type and limited analysis of the other. L2 (5–6 marks) For an accurate though undeveloped comment concentrating on only one type of good. L1 (1–4 marks) For an answer which shows some knowledge but does not indicate that the question has been fully grasped. The answer will have some correct facts but include irrelevancies. Errors of theory or omissions of analysis will be substantial.
13
Response: An increase in indirect taxation on a good raises its price, shifting the budget line leftwards in an indifference curve diagram. This results in a new equilibrium at a lower indifference curve, reflecting reduced consumer welfare. For normal goods, the income effect of a price rise leads to a decrease in demand, as consumers can afford fewer units at the higher price. The substitution effect also occurs, as consumers switch to cheaper alternatives. The combined income and substitution effects cause the budget line to pivot inwards, reducing the quantity demanded. This is shown by a movement from point A to point B on a normal good’s demand curve (DIAGRAM: Normal good demand curve with pivot from A to B). The extent of the pivot depends on the good’s price elasticity of demand: if demand is elastic, the quantity demanded falls significantly; if inelastic, the fall is smaller. Inferior goods, however, exhibit a perverse response to price changes. As price rises, the income effect dominates, causing consumers to buy more of the inferior good as they cannot afford preferred alternatives. This Giffen effect is illustrated by a rightward shift of the budget line in the indifference curve diagram, increasing quantity demanded at the higher price (DIAGRAM: Inferior good diagram with rightward budget line shift). The substitution effect still occurs, but is outweighed by the income effect, leading to an upward-sloping demand curve. The increase in indirect taxation thus increases the quantity demanded of an inferior good, unlike normal goods. The distinction hinges on whether the good is a necessity (inferior) or a luxury (normal), influencing consumer behavior in response to price changes. Ultimately, the impact of taxation on demand depends on the good’s characteristics, with normal goods experiencing reduced demand and inferior goods seeing increased demand following a price rise due to taxation.<|eot_id|>

Question: Discuss who might benefit and who might lose when a market becomes dominated by a few large firms. [13]
Mark Scheme:
b
Discuss who might benefit and who might lose when a market becomes dominated by a few large firmsDiscussion of effects of larger firms in terms of reduced output, higher prices,higher profits, but possibly more research, innovation, product branding, economies.L4 for a sound explanation with good illustrations and a clear understanding of the principles involved  9–13L3 for a competent comment with limited development. One sided discussion max 7. 7–8L2 for a limited but acceptable attempt to consider differences 5–6L1 For an answer that has some basic correct facts but includes irrelevancies and errors of theory  1–4
13
Response:
The emergence of a market dominated by a few large firms, often referred to as an oligopoly, can have far-reaching consequences for various stakeholders. On one hand, consumers may initially benefit from lower prices due to economies of scale, which enable large firms to reduce their average costs of production. For instance, if a firm expands its output, it may negotiate lower prices with suppliers, leading to cost savings that can be passed on to consumers in the form of lower prices. Additionally, large firms may invest in research and development, leading to product innovation and differentiation, which can improve product quality and choice for consumers. However, these benefits are contingent upon the firms competing with each other, either through price competition or non-price competition such as advertising. If firms collude, either tacitly or through explicit agreements, they may set prices above the competitive equilibrium, reducing consumer surplus and potentially leading to higher prices. This could occur through price-fixing agreements or output restrictions, where firms agree to limit production to maintain higher prices. Furthermore, large firms may engage in predatory pricing, where they temporarily set prices below cost to drive out smaller competitors, only to raise prices once competition is eliminated. This can lead to reduced consumer choice and higher prices in the long run.

Firms themselves may also benefit from oligopolistic market structures. Large firms can exploit economies of scale to reduce costs, increasing their profit margins. They may also enjoy barriers to entry, which prevent new firms from entering the market and competing away profits. Barriers to entry can include high sunk costs, such as significant investment in capital or advertising, which deter potential entrants. Additionally, large firms may engage in strategic behavior, such as limit pricing, where they set prices low enough to deter entry but high enough to maintain profits. This can lead to supernormal profits, which are profits above the normal level that would be expected in a perfectly competitive market. However, not all firms may benefit equally. Smaller firms may struggle to compete with larger rivals, potentially leading to their exit from the market. This can reduce competition and innovation, as smaller firms may be more agile and responsive to changing consumer preferences.

Workers may experience mixed outcomes. On one hand, large firms may offer higher wages and better working conditions due to their ability to pay. They may also invest in employee training, enhancing human capital and productivity. However, oligopolistic markets can lead to reduced labor mobility, as workers may face limited job opportunities if a few large firms dominate the market. This can reduce workers' bargaining power, potentially leading to lower wages and poorer working conditions. Furthermore, if large firms engage in predatory practices, they may drive out smaller competitors, leading to job losses in the sector. The impact on workers will depend on the specific market dynamics and the strategies employed by large firms.

The distribution of benefits and losses also depends on the market's specific characteristics. In markets with high barriers to entry, large firms may enjoy sustained profits, while consumers and smaller firms may lose out. In contrast, markets with low barriers to entry may see more competitive pressure, reducing the ability of large firms to exploit consumers. Additionally, the time period in question is crucial. In the short run, consumers may benefit from lower prices, but in the long run, reduced competition can lead to higher prices and reduced innovation. The evaluation of who benefits and who loses ultimately hinges on the interplay between market structure, firm behavior, and consumer preferences. While large firms may offer initial benefits, the potential for collusion, predatory practices, and reduced competition means that consumers and smaller firms may ultimately lose out in an oligopolistic market.<|eot_id|>

Question: To what extent do you agree that the costs of economic growth are greater than the benefits? [13]

A discussion of the costs of economic growth e.g., pollution, congestion, increase in working hours. L4 (9–13 marks) For a thorough discussion of both sides of the issue. Maximum11 if no conclusion. L3 (7–8 marks) For a competent comment which does not fully analyse both sides. An analysis of one side and limited analysis of the other. L2 (5–6 marks) For an accurate though undeveloped comment concentrating on one side. L1 (1–4 marks) For an answer which shows some knowledge but does not indicate that the question has been fully grasped. The answer will have some correct facts but include irrelevancies. Errors of theory or omissions of analysis will be substantial.
13
Response: Economic growth refers to a sustained increase in the productive capacity of an economy, typically measured by the rate of change in real Gross Domestic Product (GDP) over time. The costs and benefits of economic growth are multifaceted and can be evaluated from both microeconomic and macroeconomic perspectives. On one hand, the benefits of economic growth include higher living standards, increased employment opportunities, and improved public services. As an economy grows, the increased output and income enable governments to collect more taxes, which can be used to fund public goods and services such as healthcare, education, and infrastructure. This, in turn, enhances the quality of life for citizens and contributes to human development. For instance, economic growth can lead to better healthcare facilities, resulting in improved health outcomes and increased life expectancy. Furthermore, growth often leads to technological advancements, as firms invest in research and development to stay competitive. These innovations can improve productivity, reduce production costs, and create new industries and job opportunities, further boosting economic activity. For example, the development of renewable energy technologies has created new employment opportunities in the sector while reducing dependence on fossil fuels. Additionally, economic growth can lead to increased international trade, as a growing economy tends to have a higher demand for imports. This can foster global economic interdependence, promoting peace and cooperation among nations. However, it is essential to consider the costs of achieving this growth. One of the primary costs is environmental degradation. As economies expand, they tend to consume more natural resources and generate more waste, leading to pollution, deforestation, and climate change. The extraction and processing of raw materials, as well as the increased energy consumption associated with growth, contribute to greenhouse gas emissions and threaten biodiversity. For example, the rapid industrialization of China has resulted in severe air and water pollution, with significant health impacts on its population. Another cost is income inequality. Economic growth can exacerbate existing disparities in wealth and income, as those who are already wealthy may have better access to the capital and skills needed to take advantage of new opportunities. This can lead to social unrest and decreased social mobility, undermining the potential benefits of growth for the broader population. Furthermore, growth can lead to the depletion of non-renewable resources, compromising the ability of future generations to meet their own needs. The overexploitation of fisheries, for instance, threatens the long-term sustainability of this vital food source. In conclusion, while economic growth offers numerous benefits, including improved living standards and technological progress, its costs—particularly environmental degradation and income inequality—cannot be overlooked. The extent to which the costs outweigh the benefits depends on the context. In economies with significant environmental degradation or severe inequality, the costs may indeed be greater. However, in economies that prioritize sustainable development and equitable distribution of wealth, the benefits of growth can be more pronounced. Ultimately, a balanced approach that integrates economic, social, and environmental considerations is necessary to ensure that growth is both sustainable and equitable.<|eot_id|>

Question: Analyse the differences between a normal good, an inferior good and a Giffen good. Discuss whether knowledge of these differences is all that is required by a company considering changing the price of its product. [13]
Mark Scheme:
b

Analysis of the difference between income and substitution effects and the overall effect on demand of a change in price. Whether demand will increase, and by how much for a price fall depends on the classification of the good but also on the price elasticity of demand. The company would also need to know if it increased production how that would affect costs – and thus profits.L4 (9–13 marks): there are three aspects to the question: a clear explanation of the analysis – income, substitution; a comment on the effect on demand and a comment on the relation to revenue via elasticity.Good reasoned structure.L3 (7–8 marks): for a less developed analysis of the income substitution effects, or of the link to demand, or a weaker link to the revenue. Two aspects done reasonable well, or three less developed.L2 (5–6 marks): for an answer that either deals with one aspect well, or two with less clarity.
L1 (1–4 marks): for an answer that has some basic correct facts but includesirrelevancies and errors of theory.

13
Response:
A normal good is defined as a product for which demand increases as income rises, reflecting a positive income elasticity of demand (YED > 0). This means that as consumers’ incomes increase, they are willing to buy more of the good at any given price, shifting the demand curve to the right. For instance, luxury cars or high-end electronics typically exhibit normal good characteristics, as higher incomes enable consumers to afford more of these items. In contrast, an inferior good is a product for which demand decreases as income rises, indicating a negative YED (YED < 0). This occurs when consumers view the good as less desirable at higher income levels, opting for superior alternatives instead. An example could be budget fast food, which consumers may abandon in favor of healthier, more expensive options as their incomes grow. A Giffen good, named after economist Robert Giffen, represents a unique case where demand increases as price rises, contrary to the law of demand. This phenomenon arises when a good is inferior and its price increase makes it seem more desirable or of higher quality, leading consumers to purchase more despite the higher cost. Rice in a poor economy might exemplify a Giffen good, where a price hike could make it appear more prestigious, thereby increasing demand.

Understanding these differences is crucial for companies considering price adjustments. For normal goods, a price decrease would likely boost demand due to the positive YED, while a price increase could reduce demand. Inferior goods, however, may see demand fall with price hikes due to their negative YED, but companies must consider whether the revenue loss outweighs potential gains from higher prices. Giffen goods pose a unique challenge, as price increases could paradoxically raise demand, but this effect is highly context-dependent and may not apply universally. Beyond these demand characteristics, firms must evaluate other factors, such as production costs, market competition, and consumer preferences. For instance, if costs are rising, a price increase might be necessary to maintain profitability, regardless of demand type. Additionally, competitor pricing strategies and the overall market structure (e.g., monopoly, oligopoly) can influence the success of a price change. Consumer behavior, including brand loyalty and price elasticity, also plays a significant role. A company may need to assess whether its product is a necessity or a luxury, as this affects how price-sensitive demand will be. Furthermore, the time frame for the price adjustment is critical; short-term price cuts might stimulate demand, but long-term sustainability depends on whether the good remains desirable at the new price. Budget constraints, such as limited marketing budgets, could restrict a company’s ability to effectively communicate price changes or rebrand its product. Lastly, external factors like economic downturns or shifts in government policies (e.g., taxes, subsidies) can alter consumer income and spending habits, impacting demand independently of the good’s type. In conclusion, while recognizing the differences between normal, inferior, and Giffen goods is essential, it is only one aspect of the complex decision-making process surrounding price adjustments. Companies must integrate this knowledge with a broader analysis of market dynamics, consumer behavior, and economic conditions to make informed pricing decisions.<|eot_id|>

Question: In 2016 the Trade Unions called a strike of bus and train drivers after a demand for higher wages was rejected.Use the economic theory of wages to discuss whether a demand for higher wages is likely to be successful. [13]
Mark Scheme:
b
Analysis of the theory of wages distinguishing between perfect and imperfect markets and recognising that the success of a higher wage claim will depend on where the original wage level was and how much extra the claim was for. There is a bigger scope for wage claim success in imperfect competition. Level 4 (9–13 marks): for an analysis of wage determination including a clear analysis of MRP and a clear comparison of perfect and imperfect markets recognising the comparison of the initial and the final wage level. There should be a conclusion. (Without MRP cannot reach L4) Level 3 (7–8 marks): for a weaker analysis and critique of the possibility of wage increases but a competent explanation of imperfect market wage determination. Level 2 (5–6 marks): for a correct but undeveloped analysis with only a brief discussion. Level 1 (1–4 marks): for an answer that has some basic correct facts but includes irrelevancies and errors of theory.
13
Response:
The success of a demand for higher wages by trade unions depends on various economic factors, primarily revolving around the labour market structure and the elasticity of demand for labour. In a perfectly competitive labour market, wages are determined by the intersection of the labour supply and demand curves, with equilibrium wages set at the point where the marginal revenue product (MRP) of labour equals the marginal cost of labour (MCL). If trade unions, such as those representing bus and train drivers, demand higher wages, they are essentially attempting to shift the labour supply curve to the left or to increase the wage rate above the equilibrium level. However, whether this demand is successful hinges on the market conditions and the union's bargaining power.

In a competitive labour market, firms are price-takers, and any attempt to raise wages above the equilibrium level would lead to a surplus of labour, as firms would not be willing to pay higher wages than necessary. This surplus represents unemployed workers, making it difficult for unions to enforce higher wages without government intervention or collective bargaining agreements. The elasticity of demand for labour also plays a crucial role. Derived from the demand for the good or service produced, labour demand elasticity is influenced by factors such as the good's price elasticity, the proportion of labour costs in total costs, and the ease of substituting capital for labour. If demand for labour is inelastic (e.g., in industries with high barriers to entry or where labour is a small fraction of costs), unions may successfully negotiate higher wages without significantly reducing employment. Conversely, elastic demand (common in competitive industries with low barriers to entry) means that even small wage increases could lead to substantial job losses, undermining union demands.

The nature of the good or service produced is another critical factor. Bus and train drivers are essential for public transportation, suggesting a degree of inelasticity in demand for their labour. However, this inelasticity must be balanced against the potential for substitution with capital (e.g., automated vehicles) or the willingness of consumers to accept reduced services. In monopolistic or oligopolistic labour markets, unions may have greater leverage due to reduced competition among firms. If a union represents all workers in an industry, it can more effectively negotiate higher wages by threatening to restrict labour supply, thereby shifting the labour supply curve leftward. The success of such strategies depends on the union's ability to maintain solidarity among members and prevent non-union labour from filling any resulting vacancies.

Government policies and the overall state of the economy also influence the success of wage demands. In times of high unemployment or recession, unions may face weaker bargaining positions due to the availability of alternative labour. Conversely, during economic booms with low unemployment, firms may be more willing to accommodate wage increases to attract and retain skilled workers. Legal frameworks governing industrial action, such as the right to strike or negotiate collectively, further affect unions' bargaining power. In the context of the 2016 strike, the unions' ability to secure higher wages would depend on their capacity to disrupt services sufficiently to impose costs on employers (e.g., through lost revenue or reputational damage) that exceed the costs of meeting the wage demand. This calculus is inherently uncertain, as it depends on factors such as public sympathy, the availability of alternative transport, and the political climate regarding labour rights.

In conclusion, the success of a demand for higher wages by trade unions like those representing bus and train drivers hinges on a complex interplay of labour market conditions, the elasticity of demand for labour, the nature of the industry, and broader economic and political factors. While unions may leverage their bargaining power in certain contexts, such as oligopolistic markets or during periods of low unemployment, their ability to secure higher wages ultimately depends on their capacity to negotiate effectively with employers and navigate the legal and economic landscape. The 2016 strike highlights these challenges, as unions must balance the need to protect members' interests with the risk of alienating the public or precipitating job losses, underscoring the delicate balance between labour rights and economic realities.<|eot_id|>

Question: Distinguish between the income and substitution effects of a change in a good's price and analyse why the effect of a change in price is not always the same for different goods. [13]
Mark Scheme:
b
Distinguish between the income and substitution effects of a change in a good’s price and analyse why the effect of a change in price is not always the same for different goods. A price fall is reflected in a change in the budget line (pivot from point on axis of the good with no price change) with a subsequent change in equilibrium. The equilibrium change involves substitution and income effects. Substitution effect would be in the opposite direction to the price change. The income effect is represented by a parallel shift of the budget line is in the same direction as the substitution effect for the normal good but in the opposite direction for an inferior and Giffen good. Demand will increase for a normal good, but the extent will depend on elasticity, it will increase for an inferior good but not as much as for a normal good. For a Giffen good the final demand is less than the original demand. L4 (9–13 marks) For a reasoned and clear discussion, logically presented dealing with income, substitution effects and at least two different types of good, (normal, inferior, Giffen).  L3 (7–8 marks) For a fair but undeveloped discussion probably concentrating on income, substitution. Mention might be made of different elasticities of a normal good or of the difference between normal goods and inferior/Giffen. There would be only a brief comment on the individual demand curve or no discussion about the demand curve.  L2 (5–6 marks) For a limited explanation with a lack of development of both income/substitution and different types of good.  L1 (1–4 marks) For an answer that has some basic correct facts but includes irrelevancies and errors of theory.
13
Response:
The income and substitution effects are two distinct consequences of a price change for a good, which determine the overall impact on consumer behaviour. The income effect arises when a price change alters a consumer's real income, influencing their purchasing power. If a good's price falls, the consumer's real income increases as they can buy more with the same amount of money, leading to increased consumption of the good. Conversely, a price rise reduces real income, causing consumption to decrease. This effect is more pronounced for normal goods, where increased income from a price fall leads to higher demand, and decreased income from a price rise leads to lower demand.

The substitution effect, on the other hand, occurs as consumers adjust their consumption patterns in response to relative price changes. When a good's price rises, its relative price increases compared to other goods, making substitutes more attractive. Consumers substitute away from the more expensive good towards cheaper alternatives, reducing demand. A price fall has the opposite effect, as the good becomes relatively cheaper, encouraging substitution towards it and increasing demand. The substitution effect is present for all goods, as consumers always respond to changes in relative prices by adjusting their consumption patterns.

The combined income and substitution effects determine the overall price elasticity of demand for a good. For normal goods, both effects work in the same direction: a price fall increases demand due to increased real income (income effect) and substitution towards the cheaper good (substitution effect). However, the magnitude of these effects varies across goods. For inferior goods, the income effect is negative: a price fall reduces demand as increased real income leads consumers to buy less of the inferior good and more of superior alternatives. The substitution effect still encourages demand, but the income effect dominates, resulting in a downward-sloping demand curve.

The difference in price responses between goods stems from their unique characteristics. For necessities like food or healthcare, the income effect is relatively weak, as consumers continue to purchase these goods regardless of price changes. The substitution effect dominates, leading to relatively inelastic demand. In contrast, luxury goods exhibit strong income effects, as price changes significantly alter consumers' willingness to buy. The substitution effect is also pronounced, as luxury goods are often close substitutes for other luxuries. As a result, demand for luxuries tends to be more elastic.

Additionally, the time period considered influences the relative importance of income and substitution effects. In the short run, consumers may not fully adjust their consumption patterns, limiting the substitution effect. The income effect dominates, as consumers respond primarily to changes in their budget constraint. Over time, however, consumers become more aware of substitute goods and adjust their behaviour accordingly, strengthening the substitution effect.

In conclusion, the income and substitution effects of a price change interact to determine the overall impact on consumer demand. While the substitution effect is present for all goods, the income effect varies in magnitude and direction depending on the good's characteristics. The relative strength of these effects explains why different goods exhibit distinct price elasticities of demand, underscoring the complexity of consumer behaviour in response to price changes.<|eot_id|>

Question: Explain what economists mean by collusion and consider the view that collusion will occur only in a certain type of market structure. [13]
Mark Scheme:
b

Explain what economists mean by collusion and consider the view that collusion will occur only in a certain type of market structure.
Collusion takes place when firms find that it is in their interest to co-operate with their rivals to maximise profits. Usually this will mean that firms agree together to fix output or prices or both output and price. This is known as forming a cartel. It is also known as formal collusion and is usually illegal. Sometimes an informal agreement takes place (tacit collusion). In this a dominant firm will set the price/output and other firms will then do the same. It is possible to identify specific factors which would favour collusion. These might include firms are likely to produce similar products using similar production methods; firms will be large, often with a dominant firm; there are significant barriers to entry; the market they operate in is usually stable; governments do not interfere.
Not all market structures are likely to fulfil these conditions. Firms operating in perfectly competitive markets are price takers and there are no barriers to entry. Firms operating in monopolistic competition are very small, they sell differentiated products and there are no barriers to entry. Monopoly firms, are large but by definition, do not face competition because they control all the market, so collusion would not be relevant. Oligopoly markets consist of a few large firms, which often produce similar types of goods and use barriers to entry. These factors would produce the ideal conditions to promote collusive behaviour. Therefore it is reasonable to agree with the view that collusion will only take place in an Oligopoly market.
It should be noted that although collusion can take place it does not automatically ensure that it will. Also, Oligopoly firms will still compete with each other through alternative means such as advertising and/or product differentiation. It should also be recognised that many cartel agreements break down because of cheating or one or more firms not fully sticking to the agreed rules.
L4 (9–13 marks) For a clear explanation what is meant by collusion. The key characteristics of a market which are necessary to enable firms to collude successfully should be identified. Each of the market structures should be discussed in relation to the possibility of collusion taking place. A conclusion which addresses the specific question should then be provided. L3 (7–8 marks) For an accurate explanation of collusion and a more limited explanation with regard to the conditions necessary for it to take place. At least two types of market structures should be discussed in relation to the specific question and a brief conclusion should be provided. L2 (5–6 marks) For a briefer descriptive explanation of collusion and a reference to at least one condition necessary for it to take place. Reference to one type of market structure should be made but no conclusion will be provided in relation to the specific question. L1 (1–4 marks) For an answer that has some basic correct facts but includes irrelevancies and errors of theory.

13
Response:
Collusion refers to agreements between firms to fix prices, usually above the market equilibrium in an oligopoly market. This can be in the form of tacit collusion, which does not involve formal agreements, or in the form of a formal agreement and the formation of a cartel. In the former case, firms may choose to set prices high and maintain output levels low without any explicit communication, relying on the Nash equilibrium to ensure that no firm has an incentive to deviate from the agreed-upon price. For example, if two firms in an oligopoly market set prices high, both will benefit from higher profits as long as neither firm lowers its price. However, if one firm lowers its price, it will gain all the consumers in the market while the other firm loses out, resulting in a suboptimal Nash equilibrium where both firms set prices low. Tacit collusion can be achieved through price leadership, where one firm sets a high price and other firms follow, or through a focal point, where firms agree on a price without explicit communication. Formal collusion, on the other hand, involves explicit agreements between firms to set prices or output levels, often enforced through penalties or fines for non-compliance. Cartels, such as the Organisation of the Petroleum Exporting Countries (OPEC), are examples of formal collusion, where member firms agree to restrict oil production to maintain high prices.

Collusion can occur in various market structures, but it is most likely to occur in oligopoly markets. In perfect competition, firms are price-takers and have no incentive to collude, as they cannot influence market prices. In monopoly markets, a single firm already has complete control over prices and output, making collusion unnecessary. However, in oligopoly markets, firms have some degree of price-setting power, but their decisions are interdependent, creating an incentive to collude to avoid price wars. For instance, if two firms in an oligopoly market set prices high, they will both benefit from higher profits, but if one firm lowers its price, it will gain all the consumers, while the other firm loses out. Collusion allows firms to coordinate their price-setting decisions, reducing the uncertainty and instability inherent in oligopoly markets. Additionally, barriers to entry, such as high sunk costs or advertising expenditures, can facilitate collusion by limiting the number of firms in the market and making it more difficult for new entrants to disrupt collusive agreements.

The view that collusion will occur only in a certain type of market structure is too narrow. While oligopoly markets are more conducive to collusion, other market structures can also exhibit collusive behavior. For example, in monopolistically competitive markets, firms may engage in tacit collusion to maintain prices above the competitive equilibrium, particularly if there are few firms in the market and barriers to entry are high. In duopoly markets, where only two firms compete, collusion can be more stable, as each firm has a greater incentive to maintain the agreement, knowing that the other firm will also benefit from higher prices. Furthermore, technological advancements, such as digital communication platforms, can facilitate collusion in any market structure by reducing the costs of coordination and enforcement.

However, several factors can limit the occurrence of collusion. Asymmetric firms, with different cost structures or demand elasticities, may have conflicting interests, making it difficult to agree on a common price or output level. Additionally, firms with different time horizons or discount rates may prioritize short-term gains over long-term cooperation, leading to deviations from collusive agreements. Government policies, such as antitrust laws or price ceilings, can also deter collusion by increasing the risks and costs of detection. In conclusion, while oligopoly markets are more prone to collusion, the view that collusion will occur only in a certain type of market structure oversimplifies the complexities of interfirm coordination. Collusion can emerge in various market structures, depending on factors such as barriers to entry, firm asymmetries, and government policies.<|eot_id|>

Question: Discuss whether the existence of (i) inferior goods and (ii) advertising invalidates the underlying assumptions of those theories of demand. [13]
Mark Scheme:
b
Inferior goods would result in a different outcome when prices change from the outcome of a normal good, but they do not invalidate the underlying assumptions of the theory. Indifference curve theory can show more precisely why the difference occurs using income and substitution effects. Advertising does not necessarily invalidate the theory but it could be that persuasive advertising results in more being purchased at a higher price – this could still be explained using the theory as either utility is perceived as changing, or can be shown using the indifference curve diagrams. The assumptions have not changed. Level 4 (9–13 marks): for a reasoned and clear discussion, logically presented dealing with income, substitution, inferior and advertising.Level 3 (7–8 marks): for a fair but undeveloped discussion probably concentrating on income, substitution of inferior goods or persuasive advertising, but still with a conclusion.Level 2 (5–6 marks): for a briefer discussion of both inferior and advertising.Level 1 (1–4 marks): for an answer that has some basic correct facts but includes irrelevancies and errors of theory.
13
Response:
The theories of demand, such as the theory of consumer behaviour, rely on several key assumptions: rationality, non-satiation, and the absence of external influences. Inferior goods and advertising, however, pose potential challenges to these assumptions.

Inferior goods, by definition, are those for which demand decreases as income increases. This contradicts the assumption of non-satiation, which states that consumers will always prefer more of a good to less. Inferior goods imply that beyond a certain point, additional income leads to decreased consumption of the good, violating the monotonicity of preferences. For instance, if a consumer substitutes a superior good (e.g., organic food) for an inferior one (e.g., conventional food) as income rises, the demand curve for the inferior good becomes downward-sloping in the income range where substitution occurs. This does not invalidate the theory of demand per se, as it still assumes rational choice based on preferences. However, it complicates the analysis by introducing income effects that reverse the usual positive relationship between income and demand.

Advertising further complicates demand theory by introducing external influences on consumer preferences. Advertising can shift the demand curve outward by altering tastes or creating perceived differences between products, thereby violating the assumption of exogenous preferences. If advertising successfully manipulates consumer preferences, it undermines the rationality assumption, as consumers' choices are no longer based solely on intrinsic preferences but on extrinsic influences. For example, persuasive advertising may convince consumers that a particular brand of clothing is more desirable, independent of its objective characteristics, leading to a shift in demand that is not explained by changes in income, prices, or intrinsic preferences. This challenges the theory's predictive power, as demand becomes less determinate and more susceptible to manipulation by firms.

Despite these challenges, the existence of inferior goods and advertising does not entirely invalidate demand theory. Inferior goods can be accommodated within the framework by recognizing that income effects can lead to downward-sloping demand curves for specific goods, without contradicting the broader principle of rational choice. Advertising, while influencing preferences, operates within the bounds of consumer sovereignty; consumers ultimately decide whether to purchase based on perceived value, even if perceptions are influenced by advertising. The theory of demand remains useful for analyzing market outcomes, albeit with the caveat that real-world markets may exhibit complexities not fully captured by its assumptions.

However, the extent to which these factors invalidate demand theory depends on their prevalence and impact. If inferior goods are rare or advertising effects are marginal, the theory's core insights remain largely intact. Conversely, in markets where advertising dominates consumer decision-making or inferior goods are common, the theory's explanatory power diminishes. The time frame is also crucial; short-term demand may be more susceptible to advertising influences, while long-term preferences might reflect more intrinsic values. Ultimately, acknowledging these limitations enriches our understanding of consumer behaviour, highlighting the need for a nuanced approach that incorporates both the rational choice paradigm and the complexities of real-world markets.<|eot_id|>

Question: Discuss the extent to which monopoly producers and the consumers of their products might benefit from the existence of barriers to entry. [13]
Mark Scheme:
b

Discuss the extent to which monopoly producers and the consumers of their products might benefit from the existence of barriers to entry.
Monopoly producers might control all the market supply or sometimes the state might provide a legal definition of a monopoly, for example, a firm which controls at least 25% of the market share. Potential benefits to the monopolist might include: higher profits; increase in efficiency; increase in market share; growth of the firm. The consumer benefits might include: lower prices; higher quality product; greater availability of a product.
Responses might refer to a range of alternative barriers to entry including: economies of scale; branding/advertising; legal requirements/patents; natural monopolies; limit pricing. Good responses will choose at least two types of barrier and discuss how each might have a positive/negative effect on both the producer and the consumer. For example, economies of scale might increase Monopoly profits by lowering unit costs but also benefit the consumer by possible subsequent price reductions. Similarly, the use of limit pricing to prevent new entrants might lower prices for the consumer in the short run but lead to a higher market share and higher profits in the long run.
On a more general note, some barriers might allow a monopolist to maintain profits in the long run and invest in research and development thus achieving dynamic efficiency. These benefits might by be passed on to the consumer through lower prices, higher quality products and more choice. Alternatively, barriers might lead to complacency and X inefficiency which is likely to lead to higher prices and lower quality products.
L4 (9–13 marks): For a clear, explanation of two barriers to entry and a discussion of how each of the barriers might have both a negative and positive effect on the producer and the consumer. An attempt should be made to summarize the extent to which producers/consumers might achieve a net benefit.
L3 (7–8 marks): For a fair explanation of two barriers which focuses upon either the potential costs/benefits to the producer or consumer only or an explanation which does not attempt to examine both costs and benefits in both cases. A brief conclusion referring to the extent of the costs/benefits might be made.
L2 (5–6 marks): For a more descriptive explanation that indicates knowledge of different types of barrier to entry but does not identify specific costs/benefits and does not distinguish clearly between costs/benefits to the producer and costs/benefits to the consumer.
L1 (1–4 marks): For an answer that has some basic correct facts but includes irrelevancies and errors of theory.

13
Response:
Barriers to entry are obstacles that prevent new firms from entering a market, and they can significantly impact the welfare of both monopoly producers and their consumers. The extent to which these groups benefit from the existence of barriers to entry depends on several key factors.

Firstly, barriers to entry can lead to supernormal profits for monopoly producers. In a perfectly competitive market, firms enter or exit until profits are normalised. However, barriers such as patents, high start-up costs, or government regulations can prevent new firms from entering, allowing incumbent firms to maintain their market share and charge prices above marginal cost. This results in higher profit levels, as seen in the monopoly diagram where the profit-maximising price (P) is above the competitive equilibrium price. For instance, a firm holding a patent on a unique product can charge a price that maximises profits at MR=MC, without fear of new entrants undercutting its price. The absence of competition means that the firm does not need to invest in advertising or product differentiation, further increasing its profit margin. Therefore, monopoly producers clearly benefit from barriers to entry, as these obstacles enable them to sustain supernormal profits over time.

On the other hand, consumers may be adversely affected by barriers to entry. With fewer firms in the market, there is reduced competition, leading to higher prices and lower output levels. In a monopoly, the firm produces where MR=MC, resulting in a suboptimal output level (Qm) compared to the competitive equilibrium (Qc). Consumers pay a higher price (Pm) and receive fewer units of the good, leading to a deadweight loss triangle ABC. This loss represents the welfare forgone by consumers due to the restriction of output below its optimal level. Furthermore, barriers to entry can stifle innovation, as firms may not need to invest in research and development to maintain their market position. Without the threat of new entrants, incumbent firms may become complacent, reducing the variety of products available to consumers. For example, a monopoly producer may not invest in improving product quality or expanding its product range, as it faces no competitive pressure to do so.

However, there are scenarios in which consumers might benefit from barriers to entry. Natural monopolies, characterised by significant economies of scale, may require substantial sunk costs to enter. In such cases, barriers to entry can prevent "hit-and-run" entry, where firms enter, undercut the incumbent, and then exit, leaving consumers with higher prices once the incumbent firm has exited. By preventing this predatory behaviour, barriers to entry can ensure that the natural monopoly producer operates efficiently, passing cost savings to consumers through lower prices. Additionally, patents can incentivise firms to invest in research and development, as they guarantee a temporary monopoly period to recoup innovation costs. This can lead to the development of new products or processes that improve consumer welfare. For instance, pharmaceutical firms may only invest in costly drug development if they can secure patent protection, ensuring that consumers benefit from new medicines.

In conclusion, while monopoly producers generally benefit from barriers to entry through sustained supernormal profits, consumers may be adversely affected by higher prices and reduced output levels. However, in specific contexts such as natural monopolies or patent protection, barriers to entry can promote efficiency and innovation, ultimately benefiting consumers. The net impact depends on the type of barrier, the market structure, and the firm's behaviour, highlighting the complexity of evaluating the welfare effects of barriers to entry.<|eot_id|>

Question: Discuss the extent to which positive externalities and negative externalities explain all forms of market failure. [13]
Mark Scheme:
b

Discuss the extent to which positive externalities and negative externalities explain all forms of market failure.
Alternative forms of market failure, e.g. public goods, forms of non-perfect competition defined in terms of productive and allocative efficiency, forms of under employment of resources and, equality
L4 (9–13 marks) For an answer which develops an analysis of two alternative forms of market failure. A conclusion is reached for 12/13 marks. L3 (7–8 marks) For an answer which develops an analysis of one alternative form of market failure and comments on a second form. L2 (5–6 marks) For an answer which defines and explains alternative form(s) of market failure. L1 (1–4 marks) For an answer which has some basic correct facts but includes irrelevancies. Errors of theory or omissions of analysis will be substantial.

13
Response:
Market failure occurs when the free market fails to allocate resources efficiently, resulting in a suboptimal allocation of resources. Positive externalities and negative externalities are two key forms of market failure, arising when the production or consumption of a good generates spillover effects that benefit or harm third parties beyond the immediate buyer and seller. Positive externalities refer to benefits that accrue to external parties, such as the vaccination of individuals reducing the risk of disease transmission to others. Negative externalities, conversely, involve costs imposed on external parties, such as pollution from industrial production harming local residents. These externalities lead to market failure because they distort market signals, causing equilibrium output to diverge from the socially optimal level.

Positive externalities result in underproduction because firms do not capture the full social benefit of their output. For instance, education generates positive externalities by creating a more skilled workforce, reducing crime rates, and fostering economic growth. However, firms only consider the private benefit (revenue from tuition fees) when deciding output levels, ignoring the broader social benefits. This leads to a suboptimal equilibrium, where the marginal social benefit (MSB) exceeds the marginal private benefit (MPB), as shown in a diagram (DIAGRAM: Positive externality diagram with MSB > MPB at equilibrium). Governments may intervene with subsidies to internalize the externality, shifting the supply curve rightward to align MPB with MSB and achieve the socially optimal output level.

Negative externalities, in contrast, lead to overproduction because firms do not bear the full social cost of their output. Industrial pollution is a classic example, where firms consider only their private costs (production expenses) and ignore the external costs (health damage, environmental degradation) imposed on others. The marginal social cost (MSC) exceeds the marginal private cost (MPC), resulting in a suboptimal equilibrium (DIAGRAM: Negative externality diagram with MSC > MPC at equilibrium). Governments may impose taxes or regulations to internalize the externality, shifting the supply curve leftward to align MPC with MSC and reduce output to the socially optimal level.

While positive and negative externalities are significant forms of market failure, they do not explain all forms. Information asymmetry, where buyers or sellers possess unequal knowledge about market conditions, can lead to inefficiencies. For example, consumers may be unaware of product quality, leading to adverse selection in insurance markets. Public goods, which are non-rival and non-excludable, also exhibit market failure because firms cannot profitably supply them. Merit goods, such as healthcare, may be underconsumed due to imperfect information or income constraints. Natural monopolies, characterized by high fixed costs and decreasing average costs, can lead to allocative inefficiency if left unregulated. Finally, poverty and income inequality can result in market failure if low-income households are unable to afford essential goods and services.

In conclusion, positive externalities and negative externalities are crucial forms of market failure, arising from the mismatch between private and social costs or benefits. However, they do not encompass all forms of market failure, which also include information asymmetry, public goods, merit goods, natural monopolies, and poverty. Each type of market failure requires distinct policy interventions to correct the inefficiency and achieve a more optimal allocation of resources.<|eot_id|>

Question: In 2016 the Trade Unions called a strike of bus and train drivers after a demand for higher wages was rejected.Use the economic theory of wages to discuss whether a demand for higher wages is likely to be successful. [13]
Mark Scheme:
b
Analysis of the theory of wages distinguishing between perfect and imperfect markets and recognising that the success of a higher wage claim will depend on where the original wage level was and how much extra the claim was for. There is a bigger scope for wage claim success in imperfect competition. Level 4 (9–13 marks): for an analysis of wage determination including a clear analysis of MRP and a clear comparison of perfect and imperfect markets recognising the comparison of the initial and the final wage level. There should be a conclusion. (Without MRP cannot reach L4) Level 3 (7–8 marks): for a weaker analysis and critique of the possibility of wage increases but a competent explanation of imperfect market wage determination. Level 2 (5–6 marks): for a correct but undeveloped analysis with only a brief discussion. Level 1 (1–4 marks): for an answer that has some basic correct facts but includes irrelevancies and errors of theory.
13
Response:
The economic theory of wages suggests that the success of a demand for higher wages depends on various factors, including the type of market structure, the elasticity of demand and supply for labor, and the level of trade union power. In a perfectly competitive labor market, wages are determined by the intersection of the labor supply and demand curves. If the labor market is in equilibrium, a demand for higher wages would shift the labor supply curve to the left, resulting in a new equilibrium wage rate above the original market clearing wage. However, this assumes that the labor demand curve is relatively elastic, meaning that firms can easily substitute labor with capital or other factors of production. If the labor demand curve is inelastic, firms may be unable to reduce labor employment in response to higher wages, leading to unemployment among workers.

In contrast, a monopsony labor market, where a single firm is the sole employer of labor, may allow trade unions to negotiate higher wages more effectively. A monopsonist firm maximizes profits by equating the marginal revenue product of labor (MRP) with the marginal cost of labor (MCL), which is typically above the market equilibrium wage. If trade unions can restrict labor supply, they can shift the labor supply curve to the left, forcing the firm to pay a higher wage rate. However, this requires significant trade union power, including the ability to enforce membership and restrict labor mobility. In the case of bus and train drivers, trade unions may have an advantage due to the specialized nature of their skills and the difficulty of substituting labor with capital.

The elasticity of demand and supply for labor also plays a crucial role in determining the success of a demand for higher wages. If the demand for labor is relatively elastic, firms can easily substitute labor with other factors of production, reducing the effectiveness of trade union negotiations. Conversely, if labor demand is inelastic, firms may be forced to accept higher wages to maintain production levels. Similarly, if labor supply is relatively inelastic, trade unions may be able to negotiate higher wages without significantly reducing labor employment. In the transport sector, labor demand may be relatively inelastic due to the essential nature of bus and train services, giving trade unions greater bargaining power.

Trade union power is also critical in determining the success of a demand for higher wages. If trade unions can enforce membership and restrict labor mobility, they can negotiate higher wages more effectively. In addition, trade unions may use collective bargaining tactics, such as strikes or work-to-rule, to pressure firms into accepting higher wage rates. However, the effectiveness of these tactics depends on the level of trade union membership and the willingness of workers to participate in industrial action. In the case of the 2016 strike, the success of the demand for higher wages would depend on the level of trade union membership among bus and train drivers, as well as the willingness of workers to participate in industrial action.

In conclusion, the success of a demand for higher wages depends on various factors, including the type of market structure, the elasticity of demand and supply for labor, and the level of trade union power. While trade unions may be able to negotiate higher wages in certain sectors, such as transport, the effectiveness of their demands depends on the specific market conditions and the level of trade union power. Ultimately, the outcome of a demand for higher wages will depend on the complex interplay of these factors, as well as the willingness of firms and workers to negotiate and compromise.<|eot_id|>

Question: How far would you agree that the use of budget deficits is the most effective way to solve the problem of a deflationary gap? [13]
Mark Scheme:
b
Responses should indicate a clear understanding of what is meant by a budget deficit and the economic circumstances where governments would choose to use them. Reference should then be briefly made to the problems created by a deflationary gap and the links between these and the use of budget deficits. Some attempt should be made to discuss the effectiveness of using budget deficits and also some consideration of alternatives such as the reliance on the operation of market forces and/or the use of supply side policies. L4 (9–13): for responses that recognise there are problems associated with deficit financing such as crowding out, long term effects on the price level. Higher level four responses will then consider alternative approaches such as supply side policies and/or market liberalisation. A conclusion should be provided. L3 (7–8): for responses that analyse the links between the use of budget deficits and deflationary gaps. Clear diagrams illustrating how deficits can be used to close the gap will be provided. Some attempt should be made to develop answers which recognise that budget deficits alone are unlikely to solve problems associated with negative expectations. L2 (5–6): for an understanding of the term budget deficit and how this might provide a solution to the problem of a deflationary gap. Answers will be descriptive and not go beyond linking the policy to key issues of unemployment and low growth rates. L1 (1–4): for an answer that has some basic correct facts but includes irrelevancies and errors of theory.
13
Response: The use of budget deficits as a means to address a deflationary gap hinges on its ability to stimulate aggregate demand (AD) through government spending or tax cuts, thereby closing the gap between actual and potential output. A deflationary gap arises when the equilibrium level of real income and output is below the full employment level, leading to underutilisation of resources and potential economic stagnation. Budget deficits can be effective in this context because they directly inject funds into the economy, either by increasing government expenditure on goods and services or by reducing taxes to boost disposable income and hence consumption. For instance, if the government decides to cut income taxes, households will have more disposable income, which could encourage spending on goods and services, shifting the AD curve to the right. Similarly, direct government expenditure on infrastructure projects not only creates jobs in the construction sector but also stimulates demand for materials and services, further amplifying the multiplier effect across various industries. This multiplier effect, which depends on the marginal propensity to consume (MPC) and the tax rate, can lead to a significant increase in AD if the MPC is high, as seen in economies with a large consumer sector. However, the effectiveness of budget deficits also depends on the state of the economy. In a liquidity trap, where interest rates are near zero and households are risk-averse, additional money may be hoarded rather than spent, limiting the deficit's stimulative effect. Additionally, if the economy is close to full employment, a budget deficit could lead to demand-pull inflation, necessitating monetary policy intervention to control prices. The sustainability of budget deficits is another concern, as persistent deficits can lead to rising national debt levels. High debt servicing costs could divert funds from productive government spending, undermining long-term economic stability. Fiscal policy's effectiveness is also contingent upon the exchange rate regime. In a fixed exchange rate system, expansionary fiscal policy could lead to a balance of payments deficit, forcing the government to intervene and potentially offsetting the initial stimulus. In contrast, under a floating exchange rate, the currency may depreciate, boosting exports but also risking higher import prices and potential inflation. The time lag between implementing fiscal policy and its effects is another critical factor. Recognition lags (identifying the gap), implementation lags (passing legislation), and impact lags (effects materialising) can delay policy outcomes, making it challenging to fine-tune the economy. Furthermore, the type of good experiencing the deflationary gap is crucial. If the gap is in non-tradeable services, fiscal policy may be more effective than monetary policy, which primarily influences interest-sensitive sectors like housing and investment. Conversely, if the gap is in tradeables, exchange rate adjustments might be necessary to restore competitiveness. The budget position of the government also plays a role. A government with a low debt-to-GDP ratio has more fiscal space to implement deficits without risking a debt crisis, whereas highly indebted governments may face higher borrowing costs and reduced policy flexibility. In conclusion, while budget deficits can be an effective tool for addressing deflationary gaps by directly stimulating AD, their success depends on various factors, including the state of the economy, the exchange rate regime, the type of good affected, and the government's budget position. In some scenarios, such as a liquidity trap or an economy near full employment, alternative policies like monetary easing or supply-side reforms might be more appropriate. Ultimately, the most effective approach will likely involve a combination of fiscal and monetary measures, tailored to the specific economic conditions and structural characteristics of the economy in question.<|eot_id|>

Question: Discuss whether it is sometimes necessary to use the public sector to try to achieve economic efficiency rather than the private sector. [13]
Mark Scheme:
b
Individual actions are not always best for society as a whole. Discussion of reasons for market failure and hence the necessity/desirability of government intervention to achieve efficiency. Intervention could be by persuasion (nudge theory) rather than by enforcement, by designing choices to encourage decision-making in wider positive interests of society. Government intervention may thus be necessary, but it might not be sufficient to overcome inefficiency as there can be inefficiency in government through lack of information. L4 (9–13): for an accurate discussion of market failure, with examples and a conclusion about the need for government intervention and whether such intervention is a sufficient solution L3 (7–8): for a more limited discussion of the reasons for market failure and the need for the government but without a comment on whether such intervention is sufficient to overcome market failure L2 (5–6): for a brief analysis of market failure with few examples and no conclusion about necessity or sufficiency L1 (1–4): for an answer that has some basic correct facts but includes irrelevancies and errors of theory
13
Response:
The concept of economic efficiency refers to the optimal allocation of resources in an economy, where the marginal social benefit (MSB) of a good or service equals its marginal social cost (MSC). In theory, private sector firms driven by profit maximization can achieve efficiency through competitive markets, as firms produce where marginal revenue equals marginal cost (MR=MC). However, market failures such as externalities, public goods, and information asymmetry can lead to inefficiencies, necessitating public sector intervention to correct these failures and restore efficiency.

One primary reason for public sector involvement is the existence of externalities, where private production or consumption imposes uncompensated costs or benefits on third parties. Negative externalities, such as pollution from industrial production, result in MSC exceeding private marginal cost (MC), leading to overproduction and inefficiency. Conversely, positive externalities, like vaccination, yield MSC greater than private marginal benefit (MB), resulting in underproduction. The public sector can internalize these externalities through taxes or subsidies, aligning MSC with private MC or MB and achieving efficiency. For instance, a government might impose a carbon tax on fossil fuel producers to reflect the social cost of pollution, reducing output to the socially optimal level where MSC=MSB.

Public goods, characterized by non-rivalry and non-excludability, represent another market failure. Private firms cannot profitably supply public goods, as consumers can free-ride on others' purchases, leading to underprovision. The public sector can address this by financing public goods through taxation, ensuring their availability to all. National defense, for example, is a public good that private markets cannot efficiently provide, as its benefits are indivisible and non-excludable. Government provision ensures that defense is supplied at the optimal level, where MSB=MSC.

Information asymmetry, where one party possesses more information than another in a market transaction, can also justify public sector intervention. In healthcare, for instance, patients often lack the knowledge to make informed decisions about treatments, while providers may have incentives to oversupply or recommend unnecessary services. Public healthcare systems can mitigate this asymmetry by establishing standards, regulating provider behavior, and ensuring that patients receive appropriate care, thereby reducing inefficiencies arising from information gaps.

However, the effectiveness of public sector intervention in achieving efficiency depends on various factors. The time horizon is crucial, as short-term interventions may not address underlying structural issues, while long-term commitments can lead to path dependence and inefficiency. The nature of the good or service is also important; public provision may be more suitable for merit goods like education, where social benefits exceed private benefits, than for private goods like food, where markets can efficiently allocate resources. Additionally, the public sector's own inefficiencies, such as bureaucratic costs and political interference, can undermine its ability to correct market failures. In some cases, private sector solutions, like vouchers or subsidies, may be more effective in promoting efficiency, especially when public sector capacity is limited or corrupt.

In conclusion, while the private sector can achieve efficiency in competitive markets, public sector intervention is sometimes necessary to correct market failures and promote economic efficiency. The appropriateness of public sector involvement depends on factors like the type of good, the nature of the market failure, and the public sector's capacity to address these failures. By understanding these complexities, policymakers can design targeted interventions that harness the strengths of both sectors to achieve optimal resource allocation.<|eot_id|>

Question: To what extent do you agree that it is not possible to achieve economic growth without simultaneously causing a balance of payments deficit? [13]
Mark Scheme:
b
To what extent do you agree that it is not possible to achieve economic growth without simultaneously causing a balance of payments deficit?Answers should establish that economic growth and a stable balance of payments are key macroeconomic goals. Alternative policies required to promote economic growth should be explained and analysed. Candidates should then proceed to examine the potential impact of economic growth on the balance of payments.Alternative approaches which use circular income flow or Keynesian AD/AS analysis might be used. Evaluative comment will attempt to consider the extent of the impact of economic growth on the level of national income and imports. Similarly, analysis of the links between policies to promote economic growth and a balance of payments deficit will be discussed. For example, economic growth should lead to a rise in incomes which is likely to lead to a higher level of imports which, in turn, would cause/increase a balance of payments deficit. Evaluative comment will consider the extent of the impact of economic growth and a balance of payments deficit. A conclusion, based on the preceding analysis, will then attempt to show how far it is possible to agree with the statement under consideration. L4 (9–13 marks): For an answer that examines alternative policies to achieve economic growth. For example, short run demand side and long run supply side. Responses will analyse and evaluate the impact of at least one approach on a balance of payments deficit. A conclusion will discuss the extent to which the outcome referred to in the statement is possible. L3 (7–8 marks): For an answer which analyses the impact of economic growth on a balance of payments deficit with some evaluative comment or a response which analyses both elements of the question but makes no attempt to discuss the view under consideration.L2 (5–6 marks): For an answer which explains policies which can be introduced to achieve economic growth but focuses upon describing the potential impact on a balance of payments deficit. A conclusion will not be provided. L1 (1–4 marks): For an answer that shows some knowledge but does not indicate that the question has been fully grasped or where the answer is mostly irrelevant
13
Response:
